abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Fund Project for Comoros had
            the following ratings: the outcome was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was modest, and the Bank and borrower performance
            were both satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that
            Involvement of development stakeholders during period of
            crisis is important for effective re-engagement.
            Independence, decentralization, and strong technical
            leadership of implementing agencies, are key factors of
            success of Social Fund implementation. Implementation of
            micro-credit activities should be kept separate from
            community infrastructures or service/capacity building
            sub-project operations. If well supported, communities are
            more than ready to take over the implementation of local
            economic and social development project. This project shows,
            once more, that empowerment of communities at all stages of
            the project cycle is the best approach to achieve lasting
            results in local development projects.

5081296.trustfund:
TF029573-PHRD-POPULATION & HUMAN
            RESOURCES II,TF030620-NETHERLANDS (MDC) CONSULTANT
            TRUST FUND - FY05 - IDA ELIGIBLE COUNTRIES,TF025084-PHRD-REGIONAL SOCIAL FUND PROJECT,TF030467-DANISH CTF FY04 - SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA
5081296.majtheme: Urban development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Social protection and risk management,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Social
            Fund Project is to address the incidence of poverty amongst
            the country's poorer communities through the
            replenishment of a social fund designed to support
            demand-driven initiatives developed by such communities and,
            in doing so, to create employment and improve access to
            basic social services. The project builds on the very
            successful social fund component of the on-going Population
            and Human Resources Project. The Social Fund Project
            components are: 1) rehabilitation/construction of communal
            infrastructure for primary schools, health centers, feeder
            roads, community water supply systems, markets, etc.; 2)
            micro-credit activities, such as, subproject financing for
            income generating activities and small loan programs for
            individuals, as well as groups, particularly women; 3)
            capacity building subprojects for training of Fonds
            d'Appui au Developpement Communautaire (FADC)'s
            partners to improve their effectiveness in identifying,
            preparing, and implementing community development
            activities; and 4) training and institution capacity
            building technical assistance for FADC's investment and
            operating costs, audits, and studies.
